ques.p: To ask the Scottish Executive when it plans to consult on the findings of the Burials and Cremations Review Group.

reply.p: We are currently working up a consultation document based on the findings of the Burials and Cremations Review Group.

ques.p: To ask the Scottish Executive when it plans to bring forward legislation to amend the law on burials and cremations.

reply.p: Any legislation to amend the law on burials and cremations would be dependant on the outcome of the consultation on the Burial and Cremation Review Group’s findings. It would be inappropriate to pre-empt the outcome of the future public consultation at this time.

ques.p: To ask the Scottish Executive what the ramifications for cultural activity in Scotland are of the requirement for a certificate of sponsorship under the UK Government’s points-based immigration system.

reply.p: Our world renowned cultural festivals and events are vital to attracting tourists and artists, and contributing to our economy. It is vital that those who are coming here to contribute are welcomed, not shunned.
The UK immigration system should meet the needs of the whole of the UK and we are pressing the Home Office to ensure that the distinct needs of Scotland are taken into account.

ques.p: To ask the Scottish Executive what it can do to encourage non-EU artists to visit and perform in Scotland.

reply.p: The UK immigration system should meet the needs of the whole of the UK and we are pressing the Home Office to ensure that the distinct needs of Scotland are taken into account. We are also working with colleagues at the UK Border Agency to ensure more is done to inform Scottish-based organisers and promoters about immigration systems and regulations, and to provide support and advice where possible.

Our Relocation Advisory Service (RAS) aims to assist and advise those who wish to live and work in Scotland, including those from the cultural sector. They seek to create a seamless service that streamlines UK, Scotland and local public services to make things easier for people to move to this country to live and work. The welcoming package includes information on living and working in Scotland, cultural networks, information on diversity and equality issues, where to seek employment, accommodation and healthcare and provides information on immigration issues such as work permits and visas. People are able to contact RAS via the website at www.scotlandistheplace.com, by telephone or, if they are in Glasgow, through a face-to-face meeting.

ques.p: To ask the Scottish Executive what stage has been reached in its discussions with COSLA regarding revisions to the local government funding formula and when it expects the conclusions to be announced.

reply.p: The joint review of the local government finance distribution methodology is now well underway. The review group has been asked to make recommendations by the end of October 2009. Any agreed conclusions are likely to be announced shortly after that in order to inform the allocation of funding to local government from 2011-12.

ques.p: To ask the Scottish Executive what representations it has made to the Home Office regarding visas for non-European Economic Area crew members currently crewing Scottish boats.

reply.p: I have written to Phil Woolas, the Minister of State for Borders and Immigration, twice this year requesting a meeting to discuss the UK Border Agency’s enforcement of existing immigration laws in respect of non-EEA crew members currently crewing Scottish vessels. The Scottish Government will do everything in our power to ensure that any action taken is managed in such a way that it does not jeopardise the operation of our fleets.

ques.p: To ask the Scottish Executive when the Scottish Futures Trust’s annual report will be published.

reply.p: I refer the member to the answer to question S3W-23792 on 26 May 2009. All answers to written parliamentary questions are available on the Parliament’s website, the search facility for which can be found at http://www.scottish.parliament.uk/Apps2/Business/PQA/Default.aspx .

ques.p: To ask the Scottish Executive whether the Scottish Futures Trust’s business plan will be published before the end of 2009 and on what date.
To ask the Scottish Executive, further to the answer to question S3W-23730 by John Swinney on 26 May 2009, when the initial activities of the Scottish Futures Trust will be made public.

reply.p: The Scottish Futures Trust’s business plan for 2009-10, setting out its business objectives, activities and priorities for the current year, was published on 5 June 2009. Copies of the plan can be obtained from the Scottish Parliament’s Information Centre (Bib. number 48319).

ques.p: To ask the Scottish Executive when the Scottish Futures Trust’s website will be operational.

reply.p: The Scottish Futures Trust have stated in their recently published business plan that their website will be operational by the end of June 2009. Copies of the business plan can be obtained through the Scottish Parliament Information Centre (Bib. number 48319).

ques.p: To ask the Scottish Executive, further to the answer to question S3W-23730 by John Swinney on 26 May 2009, how it defines the short to medium term in relation to the Scottish Futures Trust’s role as a direct funder of projects.

To ask the Scottish Executive, further to the answer to question S3W-23730 by John Swinney on 26 May 2009, what timescale it considers to be in due course in relation to the Scottish Futures Trust’s development of proposals setting out how investment might be channelled for Scottish infrastructure priorities and when these proposals will be available.

reply.p: The Scottish Futures Trust (SFT) will approve release of funding for projects as part of the school building programme in 2011. SFT is currently managing the Scottish Government funding for the hub initiative and is also working on projects where funding is provided by other public bodies.

ques.p: To ask the Scottish Executive whether it considers that the Scottish Futures Trust offers a fundamentally different vision of the future of public services from that provided by previous administrations.

reply.p: Yes – it will mean a more responsible and effective delivery of public infrastructure which contrasts significantly with many of the projects undertaken previously through Private Finance Initiatives.

ques.p: To ask the Scottish Executive what evidence there is to show that the Scottish Futures Trust is providing "more bang for the people’s bucks" as the Cabinet Secretary for Finance and Sustainable Growth stated it would in a Scottish Government news release of 20 May 2008.
To ask the Scottish Executive how much money has been saved by the Scottish Futures Trust since its formation.
To ask the Scottish Executive how much money it estimates that the Scottish Futures Trust will save in 2009-10, 2010-11 and 2011-12.

reply.p: We have set the Scottish Futures Trust the clear target of achieving annual savings of between £100 million and £150 million on infrastructure investment once fully established and the work being undertaken, as set out in the published business plan which is available from the Scottish Parliament’s Information Centre (Bib. number 48319), makes clear the ways this will be achieved.

ques.p: To ask the Scottish Executive what progress has been made towards each of the Scottish Futures Trust’s objectives as outlined in the Scottish Government news release of 20 May 2008.

reply.p: As stated in the Scottish Futures Trust’s (SFT) published business plan for 2009-10, which can be obtained through the Scottish Parliament’s Information Centre (Bib. number 48319), SFT are addressing specific projects in or approaching procurement with a combined capital value of over £2.7 billion.

ques.p: To ask the Scottish Executive whether appointments of Scottish Futures Trust staff will be made under the Scottish Government’s pay policy.

reply.p: It is very important that the Scottish Futures Trust (SFT) has the scope and flexibility to recruit and retain staff with specific experience and skills which are not generally available in the public sector. I have therefore decided that SFT should not be subject to the Scottish Government’s public sector pay policy. Pay arrangements will of course be affordable, and overseen by SFT’s remuneration committee.
